_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT YOUR FACILITY:

Risk management and safety have been important concerns at Johns Manville for many years; the RMP formalizes and documents these activities.  Johns Manville is committed to conducting its operations in a safe, responsible manner and to reducing risks to health and the environment.  The Fernley plant will follow the same, proactive approach to accident prevention and mitigation and will comply fully with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), among other regulatory requirements.  These programs where implemented prior to the introduction of pentane at the site in excess of the threshold quantity.



A DESCRIPTION OF YOUR FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED:

This facility will manufacture polyisocyanurate insulation panels for the construction industry. A flammable mixture that includes two regulated substances, n-pentane and isopentane, is used in the manufacturing process.



THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The hypothetical worst-case scenario is a failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (90%), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  According to hazard modeling software using worst-case assumptions, impacts from this explosion could cause injuries and damage property located in an area between the storage tank and the hazard endpoint, which the end point is at .5 miles. 



The alternative release scenario involves a hose rupture.  This would result in the loss of 200 gallons of Pentane per minute for five minutes until the valves could be shut off.  The plant reviewed several possible scenarios, but due to safety systems in place, and equipment used, the most likely alternative release would be the hose rupture.  According to hazard modeling software using alternative release assumptions, impacts from this explosion could cause injuries and damage property located in an

area between the storage tank and the hazard endpoint, which the end point is at .1 miles. 







THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of a pentane release in accordance with the OSHA PSM standard and the EPA RMP.  Some of the specific activities in the prevention program are described below:

* An in-depth Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the system was conducted prior to startup, and numerous risk reduction measures have been implemented.  Qualified personnel revalidated the PHA on August 29 to September 2, 2016.   The plant conducted a PHA revalidation that included the Pentane Process, Static Mixer and recirculation loop, and the Dust Collector.  

* The pentane system was designed in accordance with applicable codes and standards (NFPA, ANSI, ASME, etc.)  A Pre-Startup Safety Review confirmed that construction and equipment comply with design specifications.

* Written operating procedures are used for training and directing the work of operators, who will receive refresher training at least every three years, however our facility conducts refresher training annually.

*Critical equipment is maintained, tested, and inspected on a planned, periodic basis to ensure proper operating conditions, we also use a SAP and MIP(Mechanical Integrity Program).



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

 There have been no accidents involving pentane since plant start-up in March 2003.  The plant has one Pentane release, of less than 1 paint (January 7, 2015).  The root cause of this leak was a loose packing on the valve to the rail car.  this loose packing allowed the Pentane to leak out of the valve handle. 



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

A written emergency plan is maintained at the facility, and Johns Manville personnel are trained in proper notification and evacuation procedures, per our EAP(Emergency Action Plan). In the event of an emergency, this facility would req

uest immediate assistance from the North Lyon County Fire Protection District.  To ensure the fire department has an understanding of the plant facilities, the plant will conduct annual emergency training drills with the North Lyon County Fire Department.  These drills will include chemical spills, high angle rescues, and a complete walk through of the Pentane Process.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Safety is a part of the working culture at Johns Manville. The pentane process is current state of the art and is designed, constructed, and maintained to be as safe. We also installed Siesmiz Detection System to shut down the Pentane process in an event of a earthquake, new heated LFL sensors in the outside bulk pentane storage containment and the rail car off load to improve reliability.  The plant is part of the OSHA VPP program and participates in OSHA/PSM audits every 3 years.  The plant is due for our 2nd recertification in 2017.
